meanings.definition: Spoil the quality or efficiency of
meanings.sent1: Leaving food out in the sun can vitiate its freshness.
meanings.sent2: The rain did not vitiate the strength of the new bridge.
meanings.sent3: Forgetting to refrigerate the milk may vitiate its taste.
meanings.sent4: His negative attitude seemed to vitiate the team's morale.
meanings.sent5: The virus can quickly vitiate the body's immune system.

meanings.sent1: Using expired medicine can vitiate its healing properties.
meanings.sent2: The missing signature will vitiate the contract.
meanings.sent3: Trying to start a car without keys will vitiate your efforts.
meanings.sent4: The storm's damage vitiated all our previous repair work.
meanings.sent5: A single mistake can vitiate the entire experiment.

meanings.sent1: Power can sometimes vitiate a person's morals.
meanings.sent2: The dishonest politician's actions vitiated the trust of the people.
meanings.sent3: Eating too much junk food can vitiate your health over time.
meanings.sent4: The toxic relationship slowly vitiated her self-esteem.
meanings.sent5: The negative influence of peers can vitiate a child's behavior.
